antenna: But while a current in a circuit needs a complete path , an antenna has a varying charge distribution forming a standing wave , driven by the AC .

color constancy: 3108 . The eye - brain color - sensing system can , by comparing various objects in its view , perceive the true color of an object under varying lighting conditions — an ability that is called color constancy .

waves: By coherent , we mean waves are in phase or have a definite phase relationship .

he: To that end , he delivered his “ Report on a National Bank ” in December 1790 , proposing a Bank of the United States , an institution modeled on the Bank of England .

fine structure: As mentioned , spectral lines are actually closely spaced doublets , a characteristic called fine structure , as shown in [ link ] .

break: Another milestone , called break - even , occurs when the fusion power produced equals the heating power input .

rehearsal: Memorizing these facts is rehearsal . Another strategy is chunking : you organize information into manageable bits or chunks ( Bodie , Powers , & Fitch - Hauser , 2006 ) .
elaborative rehearsal: 3921 . Use elaborative rehearsal : In a famous article , Craik and Lockhart ( 1972 ) discussed their belief that information we process more deeply goes into long - term memory .

concepts: Schemata are concepts ( mental models ) that are used to help us categorize and interpret information .
the first stage: 3942 . The first stage is the sensorimotor stage , which lasts from birth to about 2 years old .

the child: Between 5 and 8 months old , the child develops object permanence , which is the understanding that even if something is out of sight , it still exists ( Bogartz , Shinskey , & Schilling , 2000 ) .
the parent: 3985 . In authoritarian style , the parent places high value on conformity and obedience .
the parents: 3987 . With the uninvolved style of parenting , the parents are indifferent , uninvolved , and sometimes referred to as neglectful .

older , socioemotional selectivity theor: As we get older , socioemotional selectivity theory suggests that our social support and friendships dwindle in number , but remain as close , if not more close than in our earlier years ( Carstensen , 1992 ) ( [ link ] ) .

the asch effect: 4020 . The Asch effect is the influence of the group majority on an individual ’s judgment .
people: 5644 . To symbolically communicate social standing , people often engage in conspicuous consumption , which is the purchase and use of certain products to make a social statement about status .
social facilitation: Social facilitation occurs when an individual performs better when an audience is watching than when the individual performs the behavior alone .
industrial psychology: Industrial psychology is concerned with describing job requirements and assessing individuals for their ability to meet those requirements .
Prejudice: 5673 . Prejudice refers to the beliefs , thoughts , feelings , and attitudes someone holds about a group .

in - group: In short , an in - group is the group that an individual feels she belongs to , and she believes it to be an integral part of who she is .

Reciprocity: Reciprocity is the give and take in relationships .
employer: Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 makes it illegal to treat individuals unfavorably because of their race or color of their skin : An employer can not discriminate based on skin color , hair texture , or other immutable characteristics , which are traits of an individual that are fundamental to her identity , in hiring , benefits , promotions , or termination of employees .
the focus: In transactional leadership , the focus is on supervision and organizational goals , which are achieved through a system of rewards and punishments ( i.e. , transactions ) .

They: They argued for universal manhood suffrage , or voting rights for all white male adults .
organizational culture: Organizational culture encompasses the values , visions , hierarchies , norms , and interactions among its employees .
human factors psychology: Human factors psychology is the study of how workers interact with the tools of work and how to design those tools to optimize workers ’ productivity , safety , and health .
primary appraisal: A primary appraisal involves judgment about the degree of potential harm or threat to well - being that a stressor might entail .
the fight: Cannon proposed that this reaction , which he called the fight - or - flight response , occurs when a person experiences very strong emotions — especially those associated with a perceived threat ( Cannon , 1932 ) .

immunosuppression: This situation is referred to as immunosuppression , the decreased effectiveness of the immune system .
these individuals: Known as libertarians , these individuals believe government almost always operates less efficiently than the private sector ( the segment of the economy run for profit and not under government control ) , and that government actions should therefore be kept to a minimum .

couples therapy: 4155 . Couples therapy involves two people in an intimate relationship who are having difficulties and are trying to resolve them ( [ link ] ) .

therapists: 4168 . In psychoanalysis , therapists help their patients look into their past to uncover repressed feelings .
therapist: In dream analysis , a therapist interprets the underlying meaning of dreams .

continuous development: 3928 . Continuous development views development as a cumulative process , gradually improving on existing skills ( [ link ] ) .

erikson 's psychosocial development theo: Erikson ’s psychosocial development theory emphasizes the social nature of our development rather than its sexual nature .

the just - world hypothesis: The just - world hypothesis is the belief that people get the outcomes they deserve ( Lerner & Miller , 1978 ) .
zygote: A zygote begins as a one - cell structure that is created when a sperm and egg merge .

the critical or sensitive period: 3973 . Each organ of the fetus develops during a specific period in the pregnancy , called the critical or sensitive period ( [ link ] ) .

secure base: A secure base is a parental presence that gives the child a sense of safety as he explores his surroundings .
children: 3982 . In cases of resistant attachment , children tend to show clingy behavior , but then they reject the attachment figure ’s attempts to interact with them ( Ainsworth & Bell , 1970 ) .

confederate: A confederate is a person who is aware of the experiment and works for the researcher .

the patient: In free association , the patient relaxes and then says whatever comes to mind at the moment .

perceived control: Perceived control is our beliefs about our personal capacity to exert influence over and shape outcomes , and it has major implications for our health and happiness ( Infurna & Gerstorf , 2014 ) .
the relaxation response technique: The relaxation response technique combines relaxation with transcendental meditation , and consists of four components ( Stein , 2001 ) :
involuntary treatment: Involuntary treatment refers to therapy that is not the individual ’s choice .

the cell: 163 . trait: A trait is defined as a variation in the physical appearance of a heritable characteristic .

these observations: Together , these observations led to the development of the Chromosomal Theory of Inheritance , which identified chromosomes as the genetic material responsible for Mendelian inheritance .
parental types: Parental types are progeny that exhibit the same allelic combination as their parents .
karyotype: 462 . A karyotype is the number and appearance of chromosomes , and includes their length , banding pattern , and centromere position .

the karyotype: Finally , the karyotype can pinpoint translocations , which occur when a segment of genetic material breaks from one chromosome and reattaches to another chromosome or to a different part of the same chromosome .
euploid: 466 . An individual with the appropriate number of chromosomes for their species is called euploid ; in humans , euploidy corresponds to 22 pairs of autosomes and one pair of sex chromosomes .

He: He advanced the idea of a concurrent majority , a majority of a separate region ( that would otherwise be in the minority of the nation ) with the power to veto or disallow legislation put forward by a hostile majority .

enzymes: 986 . The cnidarians perform extracellular digestion in which the food is taken into the gastrovascular cavity , enzymes are secreted into the cavity , and the cells lining the cavity absorb nutrients .
induced mutations: Induced mutations are those that result from an exposure to chemicals , UV rays , x - rays , or some other environmental agent .
purine such as adenine: 495 . Transition substitution refers to a purine or pyrimidine being replaced by a base of the same kind ; for example , a purine such as adenine may be replaced by the purine guanine .

three of the 64 codons: 503 . In addition to instructing the addition of a specific amino acid to a polypeptide chain , three of the 64 codons terminate protein synthesis and release the polypeptide from the translation machinery .
transcription bubble: The region of unwinding is called a transcription bubble .
the template strand: Transcription always proceeds from the same DNA strand for each gene , which is called the template strand .
downstream nucleotides: Conversely , nucleotides following the initiation site are denoted with “ + ” numbering and are called downstream nucleotides .

splicing: The process of removing introns and reconnecting exons is called splicing ( [ link ] ) .

these proteins: These proteins are moved to the proteasome , an organelle that functions to remove proteins , to be degraded ( [ link ] ) .
Biotechnology: 569 . Biotechnology is the use of biological agents for technological advancement .
gel electrophoresis: 474 . Gel electrophoresis is a technique used to separate DNA fragments of different sizes .

recombinant dna molecules because they a: 581 . Plasmids with foreign DNA inserted into them are called recombinant DNA molecules because they are created artificially and do not occur in nature .

a: A collision in which the objects stick together is sometimes called a perfectly inelastic collision because it reduces internal kinetic energy more than does any other type of inelastic collision .
transgenic: If the foreign DNA that is introduced comes from a different species , the host organism is called transgenic .

wealth: 4640 . Income is a flow of money received , often measured on a monthly or an annual basis ; wealth is the sum of the value of all assets , including money in bank accounts , financial investments , a pension fund , and the value of a home .
employment discrimination: 4659 . The Civil Rights Act of 1964 prohibits employment discrimination based on race , color , religion , sex , or national origin .
many economic transactions: 4667 . Many economic transactions are made in a situation of imperfect information , where either the buyer , the seller , or both , are less than 100 % certain about the qualities of what is being bought and sold .
the transaction: 4668 . Also , the transaction may be characterized by asymmetric information , in which one party has more information than the other regarding the economic transaction .
thick market: By contrast , a market with many buyers and sellers is called a thick market .

the seller: The seller may also offer a buyer a chance to buy a service contract , where the buyer pays an extra amount and the seller agrees to fix anything that goes wrong for a set time period .

risk group: A risk group can be defined as a group that shares roughly the same risks of an adverse event occurring .
venture capital firms: 4706 . Venture capital firms make financial investments in new companies that are still relatively small in size , but that have potential to grow substantially .
the entire company: Stock represents ownership of a firm ; that is , a person who owns 100 % of a company ’s stock , by definition , owns the entire company .
the stock of a company: The stock of a company is divided into shares .
capital gain: The increase in the value of the stock ( or of any asset ) between when it is bought and when it is sold is called a capital gain .

the expected rate of return: 4724 . The expected rate of return refers to how much a project or an investment is expected to return to the investor , either in future interest payments , capital gains , or increased profitability .

simple interest: 4745 . Simple interest is an interest rate calculation only on the principal amount .
rational voter: 4748 . A rational voter will recognize that one vote is extremely unlikely to make a difference .

special interest groups: ) Special interest groups are groups that are small in number relative to the nation , but quite well organized and focused on a specific issue .
pork - barrel spending: Whether any specific item qualifies as pork can be controversial , of course , but at least by this measure , pork - barrel spending totaled $ 2.7 billion in 2014.Pork - barrel spending can be encouraged by logrolling , an action in which all members of a group of legislators agree to vote for a package of otherwise unrelated laws that they individually favor .
the median voter theory: The median voter theory argues that politicians will try to match policies to what pleases the median voter preferences .
overall economy: The size of a nation ’s overall economy is typically measured by its gross domestic product ( GDP ) , which is the value of all final goods and services produced within a country in a given year .

gdp deflator: 4787 . GDP deflator is a price index measuring the average prices of all goods and services included in the economy .
recession: 4791 . A significant decline in real GDP is called a recession .
depression: 4792 . An especially lengthy and deep recession is called a depression .
the trough: The highest point of the economy , before the recession begins , is called the peak ; conversely , the lowest point of a recession , before a recovery begins , is called the trough .
microeconomic production function: 4811 . A microeconomic production function describes the inputs and outputs of a firm , or perhaps an industry .
aggregate production function: In macroeconomics , the connection from inputs to outputs for the entire economy is called an aggregate production function .
the category of physical capital: 4814 . The category of physical capital includes the plant and equipment used by firms and also things like roads ( also called infrastructure ) .
the labor market: In a supply - and - demand model of a labor market , as illustrated in [ link ] , the labor market should move toward an equilibrium wage and quantity .
the structurally unemployed: The structurally unemployed are individuals who have no jobs because they lack skills valued by the labor market , either because demand has shifted away from the skills they do have , or because they never learned any skills .

most pensions: Most pensions have traditionally been set as a fixed nominal dollar amount per year at retirement .
high and variable inflation: 4877 . High and variable inflation means that the incentives in the economy to adjust in response to changes in prices are weaker .
say 's law: Say ’s law is : “ Supply creates its own demand . ” As a matter of historical accuracy , it seems clear that Say never actually wrote down this law and that it oversimplifies his beliefs , but the law lives on as useful shorthand for summarizing a point of view . The intuition behind Say ’s law is that each time a good or service is produced and sold , it generates income that is earned for someone : a worker , a manager , an owner , or those who are workers , managers , and owners at firms that supply inputs along the chain of production .
business failures: A recession is a situation in which the economy as a whole is shrinking in size , business failures outnumber the remaining success stories , and many firms end up suffering losses and laying off workers .
the near: The U.S. government has implemented a number of programs to assist those below the poverty line and those who have incomes just above the poverty line , who are referred to as the near - poor .
federally funded program: 4632 . Often called “ food stamps , ” Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program ( SNAP ) is a federally funded program , started in 1964 , in which each month poor people receive a card like a debit card that they can use to buy food .

the lorenz curve: The Lorenz curve shows the cumulative share of population on the horizontal axis and the cumulative percentage of total income received on the vertical axis .
labor union: 4647 . A labor union seeks to change the balance of power between employers and workers by requiring employers to deal with workers collectively , rather than as individuals .

president obama: 5962 . In 2009 , President Obama signed the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act ( ARRA ) , which provided immediate economic - crisis management assistance such as helping local and state economies ride out the Great Recession and shoring up the country ’s banking sector .
monetary damages: The Civil Rights Act of 1991 provides monetary damages in cases of intentional employment discrimination .
their summer recess: In August 2009 , many members of the U.S. Congress used their summer recess to return to their home districts and hold town hall - style meetings to discuss President Obama ’s proposed changes to the U.S. healthcare system .
Insurance: 4683 . Insurance is a method that households and firms use to prevent any single event from having a significant detrimental financial effect .
premiums: Generally , households or firms with insurance make regular payments , called premiums .
employers in every state: 4686 . Unemployment insurance : Employers in every state pay a small amount for unemployment insurance , which goes into a fund that is used to pay benefits to workers for a period of time , usually six months , after they lose their jobs .
Employers: 4689 . Workman ’s compensation insurance : Employers are required by law to pay a small percentage of the salaries that they pay into funds , typically run at the state level , that are used to pay benefits to workers who suffer an injury on the job .
moral hazard: 4692 . Moral hazard refers to the case when people engage in riskier behavior with insurance than they would if they did not have insurance .
adverse selection: 4698 . Adverse selection refers to the problem in which the buyers of insurance have more information about whether they are high - risk or low - risk than the insurance company does .
investors in that fund: Typically , a venture capital fund invests in a number of firms , and then investors in that fund receive returns according to how the fund as a whole performs . corporate bond: 4710 . A corporate bond is issued by firms , but bonds are also issued by various levels of government .
initial public offering: A firm ’s first sale of stock to the public is called an initial public offering ( IPO ) .
private company: 4719 . A private company is owned by the people who run it on a day - to - day basis .

feature on lehman brothers: 4722 . Risk: Risk measures the uncertainty of that project ’s profitability .
checking account: A checking account typically pays little or no interest , but it facilitates transactions by giving you easy access to your money , either by writing a check or by using a debit card ( that is , a card which works like a credit card , except that purchases are immediately deducted from your checking account rather than being billed separately through a credit card company ) .
savings account: A savings account typically pays some interest rate , but getting the money typically requires you to make a trip to the bank or an automatic teller machine ( or you can access the funds electronically ) .
the bond yield: 4737 . The bond yield measures the rate of return a bond is expected to pay over time .
compound interest: 4746 . Compound interest is an interest rate calculation on the principal plus the accumulated interest .
Democracy: 4761 . Democracy is sometimes summed up ( and oversimplified ) in two words : “ Majority rule . ”
voting cycle: 4764 . The situation in which Choice A is preferred by a majority over Choice B , Choice B is preferred by a majority over Choice C , and Choice C is preferred by a majority over Choice A is called a voting cycle .
this demand: 4924 . This demand is determined by a number of factors , but one of them is the price level — recall though , that the price level is an index number such as the GDP deflator that measures the average price of the things we buy .
the trade balance: The gap between exports and imports is called the trade balance .
net national product: 4783 . Net national product ( NNP ) is calculated by taking GNP and then subtracting the value of how much physical capital is worn out , or reduced in value because of aging , over the course of a year .
depreciation: The process by which capital ages and loses value is called depreciation .
the real value: The real value refers to the same statistic after it has been adjusted for inflation .
the business cycle: The movement of the economy from peak to trough and trough to peak is called the business cycle .
exchange rates: 4797 . Exchange rates are expressed either as the units of country A ’s currency that need to be traded for a single unit of country B ’s currency ( for example , Japanese yen per British pound ) , or as the inverse ( for example , British pounds per Japanese yen ) .
market exchange rates: Market exchange rates vary on a day - to - day basis depending on supply and demand in foreign exchange markets .
the industrial revolution: The Industrial Revolution refers to the widespread use of power - driven machinery and the economic and social changes that resulted in the first half of the 1800s .

capital deepening: 4818 . When society increases the level of capital per person , the result is called capital deepening .
the neoclassical growth consensus: The neoclassical growth consensus uses the aggregate production function to suggest that the period of modern economic growth came about because of increases in inputs such as technology and physical and human capital .

price indices: 4855 . Price indices are created to calculate an overall average change in relative prices over time .
CPI: 4860 . As we ’ve learned , CPI measures prices as they affect everyday household spending .
core inflation index: Well , a core inflation index is typically calculated by taking the CPI and excluding volatile economic variables .
social security: Also , Social Security is funded by payroll taxes , which are imposed on the income earned up to a certain amount — $ 117,000 in 2014 .
the economy: If imports exceed exports , the economy is said to have a trade deficit .
high level of trade: A high level of trade indicates that a good portion of the nation ’s production is exported .

the bottom line: 4914 . The bottom line remains , however , that every sale represents income to someone , and so , Say ’s law argues , a given value of supply must create an equivalent value of demand somewhere else in the economy .
neoclassical economists: Because Jean - Baptiste Say , Adam Smith , and other economists writing around the turn of the nineteenth century who discussed this view were known as “ classical ” economists , modern economists who generally subscribe to the Say ’s law view on the importance of supply for determining the size of the macroeconomy are called neoclassical economists .
Demand: 4917 . The alternative to Say ’s law , with its emphasis on supply , can be named Keynes ’ law : “ Demand creates its own supply . ”
artificially high levels of epo: Because red blood cells increase the viscosity of blood , artificially high levels of EPO can cause severe health risks . The thymus is found behind the sternum ; it is most prominent in infants , becoming smaller in size through adulthood .
aldosterone: 1530 . In contrast to ADH , which promotes the reabsorption of water to maintain proper water balance , aldosterone maintains proper water balance by enhancing Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion from extracellular fluid of the cells in kidney tubules .
mineralocorticoid: Because it is produced in the cortex of the adrenal gland and affects the concentrations of minerals Na+ and K+ , aldosterone is referred to as a mineralocorticoid , a corticosteroid that affects ion and water balance .

Prolactin: 1536 . Prolactin stimulates the production of milk by the mammary glands following childbirth .
diabetes mellitus: 1539 . Impaired insulin function can lead to a condition called diabetes mellitus , the main symptoms of which are illustrated in [ link ] .

stressful stimuli: 1561 . the ribs: The ribs are 12 pairs of long , curved bones that attach to the thoracic vertebrae and curve toward the front of the body , forming the ribcage .

the clavicles: 1584 . The clavicles are S - shaped bones that position the arms on the body .
articulation: 1587 . An articulation is any place at which two bones are joined .

the knee joint: 1596 . At the distal end , the femur , tibia , and patella form the knee joint .
the patella: The patella is embedded in the tendon of the femoral extensors ( quadriceps ) .
the tarsals: 1599 . The tarsals are the seven bones of the ankle .
the ankle: The ankle transmits the weight of the body from the tibia and the fibula to the foot .
the term: In sociology , the term is used to refer to a religious group that most all members of a society belong to .

angular movements: 1614 . Angular movements are produced when the angle between the bones of a joint changes .
example of adduction: 1620 . Movement of the limbs inward after abduction is an example of adduction .

the sarcolemma: 1645 . The sarcolemma is the site of action potential conduction , which triggers muscle contraction .
myofilaments: 1647 . Myofibrils are composed of smaller structures called myofilaments .
Tropomyosin: 1651 . Tropomyosin blocks myosin binding sites on actin molecules , preventing cross - bridge formation and preventing contraction in a muscle without nervous input .
long bones: 1657 . Long bones are longer than they are wide and have a shaft and two ends .

ossification , or osteogenesis: 1674 . Ossification , or osteogenesis , is the process of bone formation by osteoblasts .

air: 1681 . From the nasal cavity , air passes through the pharynx ( throat ) and the larynx ( voice box ) , as it makes its way to the trachea ( [ link ] ) .
the respiratory bronchioles: In humans , bronchioles with a diameter smaller than 0.5 mm are the respiratory bronchioles .
approximately 100 alveolar sacs: At the end of each duct are approximately 100 alveolar sacs , each containing 20 to 30 alveoli that are 200 to 300 microns in diameter .
partial pressure: 2850 . Partial pressure is defined as the pressure a gas would create if it occupied the total volume available .

pleurisy results: Pleurisy results when these layers of tissue become inflamed ; it is painful because the inflammation increases the pressure within the thoracic cavity and reduces the volume of the lung .
the walls of the alveoli: In emphysema , which mostly arises from smoking tobacco , the walls of the alveoli are destroyed , decreasing the surface area for gas exchange .
carbon dioxide: In this system , carbon dioxide diffuses into the red blood cells .

platelets: Blood is actually a term used to describe the liquid that moves through the vessels and includes plasma ( the liquid portion , which contains water , proteins , salts , lipids , and glucose ) and the cells ( red and white cells ) and cell fragments called platelets .
the serum: 1746 . The plasma component of blood without the coagulation factors is called the serum .
the biscuspid or mitral valve: 1749 . The valve separating the chambers on the left side of the heart valve is called the biscuspid or mitral valve .
the myocardium: 1753 . The myocardium consists of the heart muscle cells that make up the middle layer and the bulk of the heart wall .
the cardiac cycle: The cardiac cycle is the coordination of the filling and emptying of the heart of blood by electrical signals that cause the heart muscles to contract and relax .
the iliac artery: 1764 . The iliac artery takes blood to the lower limbs .
Veins: Veins are blood vessels that bring blood back to the heart .
lymph nodes: Lymph nodes are specialized organs that filter the lymph by percolation through a maze of connective tissue filled with white blood cells .
Osmoregulation: Osmoregulation is the process of maintenance of salt and water balance ( osmotic balance ) across membranes within the body ’s fluids , which are composed of water , plus electrolytes and non - electrolytes .
electrolyte: An electrolyte is a solute that dissociates into ions when dissolved in water .
the molarity of a solution: 1780 . The molarity of a solution is the number of moles of solute per liter of solution .
the molality of a solution: The molality of a solution is the number of moles of solute per kilogram of solvent .
the renal fascia: 1786 . The outermost layer is a tough connective tissue layer called the renal fascia .

the ureters: The ureters are urine - bearing tubes that exit the kidney and empty into the urinary bladder .
the loop: 1806 . The second part is called the loop of Henle , or nephritic loop , because it forms a loop ( with descending and ascending limbs ) that goes through the renal medulla .
the glomerular capillary bed: 1809 . Within the glomerulus , the network of capillaries is called the glomerular capillary bed .
tubular reabsorption: Most of the solutes get reabsorbed in the PCT by a process called tubular reabsorption .
the gingko biloba: 909 . The single surviving species of the gingkophytes group is the Gingko biloba ( [ link ] ) .
collectively the corolla: Petals , collectively the corolla , are located inside the whorl of sepals and often display vivid colors to attract pollinators .

homeoboxes: 945 . These genes that determine animal structure are called “ homeotic genes , ” and they contain DNA sequences called homeoboxes .

tissues: This larval form , characteristically shaped like a deerstalker cap , devours tissues from the young worm for survival before metamorphosing into the adult - like morphology .

cells of the meristematic tissue: 1117 . Cells of the meristematic tissue are found in meristems , which are plant regions of continuous cell division and growth .

its phenomena and processes: However , those fields of science related to the physical world and its phenomena and processes are considered natural sciences .

variable: 5249 . To a mathematician or an economist , a variable is the name given to a quantity that may assume a range of values .

reference sections: There are usually acknowledgment and reference sections as well as an abstract ( a concise summary ) at the beginning of the paper .

organelles: Some cells contain aggregates of macromolecules surrounded by membranes ; these are called organelles .

the hydrocarbons we have discussed: 106 . So far , the hydrocarbons we have discussed have been aliphatic hydrocarbons , which consist of linear chains of carbon atoms .
monomers: 115 . Most macromolecules are made from single subunits , or building blocks , called monomers .

its primary structure: 143 . The unique sequence of amino acids in a polypeptide chain is its primary structure .

chemical energy: The type of potential energy that exists within chemical bonds , and is released when those bonds are broken , is called chemical energy ( [ link ] ) .

high temperatures: High temperatures will eventually cause enzymes , like other biological molecules , to denature , a process that changes the natural properties of a substance .
some inhibitor molecules: 263 . Some inhibitor molecules bind to enzymes in a location where their binding induces a conformational change that reduces the affinity of the enzyme for its substrate .

the opm: The OPM has responsibility for recruiting , interviewing , and testing potential government employees in order to choose those who should be hired .
the acquisitive model: The acquisitive model proposes that bureaucracies are naturally competitive and power - hungry .

for an approach known: They called for an approach known as supply - side economics , which argues that economic growth is largely a function of the productive capacity of a country .

some house and senate members: Some House and Senate members ask to serve on the foreign policy committees , such as the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations , the House Foreign Affairs Committee , and the two defense committees ( [ link ] ) .

the hypophysis: The hypothalamus contains autonomic centers that control endocrine cells in the adrenal medulla via neuronal control . the hypophyseal portal system: A portal system carries blood from one capillary network to another ; therefore , the hypophyseal portal system allows hormones produced by the hypothalamus to be carried directly to the anterior pituitary without first entering the circulatory system . these glands: These glands are located on the posterior surface of the thyroid gland , as shown in [ link ] .
every stage of life ,: The sacraments , or special ceremonies of the Church , marked every stage of life , from birth to maturation , marriage , and burial , and brought people into the church on a regular basis .
the reconquista: By the eleventh century , a major Christian holy war called the Reconquista , or reconquest , had begun to slowly push the Muslims from Spain .
this drive: This drive was actually an extension of the earlier military conflict between Christians and Muslims for domination of the Holy Land ( the Biblical region of Palestine ) , known as the Crusades .
the quipu: They communicated and kept records using a system of colored strings and knots called the quipu ( [ link ] ) .
Spain: Spain granted encomiendas — legal rights to native labor — to conquistadors who could prove their service to the crown .

the english: 2158 . By choosing to settle along the rivers on the banks of the Chesapeake , the English unknowingly placed themselves at the center of the Powhatan Empire , a powerful Algonquian confederacy of thirty native groups with perhaps as many as twenty - two thousand people .
iron awls: For example , iron awls made the creation of shell beads among the native people of the Eastern Woodlands much easier , and the result was an astonishing increase in the production of wampum , shell beads used in ceremonies and as jewelry and currency .
the glorious revolution: 2173 . The Glorious Revolution also led to the English Toleration Act of 1689 , a law passed by Parliament that allowed for greater religious diversity in the Empire .
this act: This act granted religious tolerance to nonconformist Trinitarian Protestants ( those who believed in the Holy Trinity of God the Father , Son , and Holy Ghost ) , such as Baptists ( those who advocated adult baptism ) and Congregationalists ( those who followed the Puritans ’ lead in creating independent churches ) .
the freemasons: 2176 . The Freemasons were a fraternal society that advocated Enlightenment principles of inquiry and tolerance .
the monarchy: 2179 . The monarchy was dissolved , and England became a republic : a state without a king .
oliver cromwell: Oliver Cromwell headed the new English Commonwealth , and the period known as the English interregnum , or the time between kings , began .
primary goal: 2182 . Creating wealth for the Empire remained a primary goal , and in the second half of the seventeenth century , especially during the Restoration , England attempted to gain better control of trade with the American colonies .
the print: The print shows the Boston Tea Party , a protest against the Tea Act of 1773 , and the Liberty Tree , an elm tree near Boston Common that became a rallying point against the Stamp Act of 1765 .

citizens in the republic: The vision of an American republic put forward by Paine included the idea of popular sovereignty : citizens in the republic would determine who would represent them , and decide other issues , on the basis of majority rule .
the american forces: 2215 . Whereas the British could pay in gold and silver , the American forces relied on paper money , backed by loans obtained in Europe .
one pathway from bondage: Private manumissions , by which slaveholders freed their slaves , provided one pathway from bondage .
Pennsylvania: Instead , Pennsylvania had a one - house — a unicameral — legislature .
james madison: 2226 . James Madison put forward a proposition known as the Virginia Plan , which called for a strong national government that could overturn state laws ( [ link ] ) .
the plan: The plan featured a bicameral or two - house legislature , with an upper and a lower house .
each state: His Connecticut Compromise , also known as the Great Compromise , outlined a different bicameral legislature in which the upper house , the Senate , would have equal representation for all states ; each state would be represented by two senators chosen by the state legislatures .
the french king: The French king was executed in January 1793 ( [ link ] ) , and the next two years became known as the Terror , a period of extreme violence against perceived enemies of the revolutionary government .
families: Under the “ Rhode Island system , ” families were hired .
thomas skidmore: Thomas Skidmore , from Connecticut , was the outspoken organizer of the Working Men ’s Party , which lodged a radical protest against the exploitation of workers that accompanied industrialization .
the preeminent example: The preeminent example was the Erie Canal ( [ link ] ) , which linked the Hudson River , and thus New York City and the Atlantic seaboard , to the Great Lakes and the Mississippi River Valley .
Deference: Deference was the practice of showing respect for individuals who had distinguished themselves through military accomplishments , educational attainment , business success , or family pedigree .
van buren: 2266 . In this way , Van Buren helped create a political machine of disciplined party members who prized loyalty above all else , a harbinger of future patronage politics in the United States .
some fifteen thousand cherokee: 2278 . In a series of forced marches , some fifteen thousand Cherokee were finally relocated to Oklahoma .
the spanish mexican government: 2287 . After the 1819 Adams - Onís Treaty defined the U.S. - Mexico boundary , the Spanish Mexican government began actively encouraging Americans to settle their northern province .
empresario: An empresario was someone who brought settlers to the region in exchange for generous grants of land .
rockers: Although some were able to find gold by panning for it or shoveling soil from river bottoms into sieve - like contraptions called rockers , most did not .
barnburners because they were likened: At the party ’s New York State convention in Buffalo , Martin Van Buren ’s antislavery supporters — called Barnburners because they were likened to farmers who were willing to burn down their own barn to get rid of a rat infestation — spoke in favor of the proviso .
cotton boom: However , following the War of 1812 , a huge increase in production resulted in the so - called cotton boom , and by midcentury , cotton became the key cash crop ( a crop grown to sell rather than for the farmer ’s sole use ) of the southern economy and the most important American commodity .
german protestant migrants: 2317 . German Protestant migrants formed several pietistic societies : communities that stressed transformative individual religious experience or piety over religious rituals and formality .

the operation of the law: 2332 . The operation of the law further alarmed northerners and confirmed for many the existence of a “ Slave Power ” — that is , a minority of elite slaveholders who wielded a disproportionate amount of power over the federal government , shaping domestic and foreign policies to suit their interests .
the people: In what became known as the Freeport Doctrine , Douglas adamantly upheld popular sovereignty , declaring : “ It matters not what way the Supreme Court may hereafter decide as to the abstract question whether slavery may or may not go into a territory under the Constitution , the people have the lawful means to introduce it or exclude it as they please . ” The Freeport Doctrine antagonized southerners and caused a major rift in the Democratic Party .
the confederate congress: Concerned about the resistance to and unhappiness with the government measures , in 1862 , the Confederate Congress gave President Davis the power to suspend the writ of habeas corpus , the right of those arrested to be brought before a judge or court to determine whether there is cause to hold the prisoner .
thousands of slaves: 2356 . Since the beginning of the war , thousands of slaves had fled to the safety of Union lines .
everything: On Sherman ’s March to the Sea , the Union army , seeking to demoralize the South , destroyed everything in its path , despite strict instructions regarding the preservation of civilian property .
the ironclad oath: Among other stipulations , the Wade - Davis Bill called for a majority of voters and government officials in Confederate states to take an oath , called the Ironclad Oath , swearing that they had never supported the Confederacy or made war against the United States .
the ama: The AMA used the knowledge and skill it had acquired while working in missions in Africa and with American Indian groups to establish and run schools for freed slaves in the postwar South .
store owners: Under the crop - lien system , store owners extended credit to farmers under the agreement that the debtors would pay with a portion of their future harvest .
the group: 2377 . Despite the great variety in Klan membership , on the whole , the group tended to direct its attention toward persecuting freed people and people they considered carpetbaggers , a term of abuse applied to northerners accused of having come to the South to acquire wealth through political power at the expense of southerners .
the colorful term: The colorful term captured the disdain of southerners for these people , reflecting the common assumption that these men , sensing great opportunity , packed up all their worldly possessions in carpetbags , a then - popular type of luggage , and made their way to the South .
themselves redeemers: Those committed to rolling back the tide of Radical Reconstruction in the South called themselves redeemers , a label that expressed their desire to redeem their states from northern control and to restore the antebellum social order whereby blacks were kept safely under the boot heel of whites .
the homestead act: 2383 . The Homestead Act allowed any head of household , or individual over the age of twenty - one — including unmarried women — to receive a parcel of 160 acres for only a nominal filing fee .
small group of trustees: In this arrangement , a small group of trustees possess legal ownership of a business that they operate for the benefit of other investors .
this philosophy: This philosophy stated that all Christians , whether they were church leaders or social reformers , should be as concerned about the conditions of life in the secular world as the afterlife , and the Reverend Washington Gladden was a major advocate .
political philosopher herbert spencer: 2416 . Political philosopher Herbert Spencer took Darwin ’s theory of evolution further , coining the actual phrase “ survival of the fittest , ” and later helping to popularize the phrase social Darwinism to posit that society evolved much like a natural organism , wherein some individuals will succeed due to racially and ethnically inherent traits , and their ability to adapt .
Economics: 4312 . Economics is the study of how humans make decisions in the face of scarcity .
Smith: In the first chapter , Smith introduces the division of labor , which means that the way a good or service is produced is divided into a number of tasks that are performed by different workers , instead of all the tasks being done by the same person .
market: A market is an institution that brings together buyers and sellers of goods or services , who may be either individuals or businesses .
Exports: 4336 . Exports are the goods and services that are produced domestically and sold abroad .
allocative efficiency: 4351 . Allocative efficiency means that the particular mix of goods a society produces represents the combination that society most desires .
unitary elasticities: Unitary elasticities indicate proportional responsiveness of either demand or supply , as summarized in [ link ] .
tax incidence: The analysis , or manner , of how the burden of a tax is divided between consumers and producers is called tax incidence .
explicit costs: Explicit costs are out - of - pocket costs , that is , payments that are actually made .
economic profit: Economic profit is total revenue minus total cost , including both explicit and implicit costs .
fixed costs: 4390 . Fixed costs are expenditures that do not change regardless of the level of production , at least not in the short term .
price: 4406 . What a buyer pays for a unit of the specific good or service is called price .
the quantity demanded: The total number of units purchased at that price is called the quantity demanded .
supply schedule: A supply schedule is a table , like [ link ] , that shows the quantity supplied at a range of different prices .
the quantity of one good: In a budget constraint line , the quantity of one good is measured on the horizontal axis and the quantity of the other good is measured on the vertical axis .
the third column: The third column shows marginal utility , which is the additional utility provided by one additional unit of consumption .
the income effect: The income effect is that a higher price means , in effect , the buying power of income has been reduced ( even though actual income has not changed ) , which leads to buying less of the good ( when the good is normal ) .
behavioral economics: So , behavioral economics seeks to enrich the understanding of decision - making by integrating the insights of psychology into economics .
Industries: 4477 . Industries differ from one another in terms of how many sellers there are in a specific market , how easy or difficult it is for a new firm to enter , and the type of products that are sold .
the old and new firms: 4490 . For a decreasing cost industry , as the market expands , the old and new firms experience lower costs of production , which makes the new zero - profit level intersect at a lower price than before .
One: 4496 . One is natural monopoly , where the barriers to entry are something other than legal prohibition .
the other: The other is legal monopoly , where laws prohibit ( or severely limit ) competition .
exclusive patent rights: A patent gives the inventor the exclusive legal right to make , use , or sell the invention for a limited time ; in the United States , exclusive patent rights last for 20 years .
one method: One method is known as predatory pricing , in which a firm uses the threat of sharp price cuts to discourage competition .
price takers: If you recall , price takers are firms that have no market power .
oligopolistic markets: Oligopolistic markets are those dominated by a small number of firms .
zero economic profit: A zero economic profit means the firm ’s accounting profit is equal to what its resources could earn in their next best use .
Oligopoly: Oligopoly arises when a small number of large firms have all or most of the sales in an industry .
collusion: 4529 . When firms act together in this way to reduce output and keep prices high , it is called collusion .
cartel: A group of firms that have a formal agreement to collude to produce the monopoly output and sell at the monopoly price is called a cartel .
another: 4537 . One example of the pressure these firms can exert on one another is the kinked demand curve , in which competing oligopoly firms commit to match price cuts , but not price increases .
acquisition: When one firm purchases another , it is called an acquisition .
these large firms: 4543 . In many cases , these large firms were organized in the legal form of a “ trust , ” in which a group of formerly independent firms were consolidated together by mergers and purchases , and a group of “ trustees ” then ran the companies as if they were a single firm .
early tool: 4547 . An early tool was the concentration ratio , which measures what share of the total sales in the industry are accounted for by the largest firms , typically the top four to eight firms .
antitrust law: 4553 . Antitrust law includes rules against restrictive practices — practices that do not involve outright agreements to raise price or to reduce the quantity produced , but that might have the effect of reducing competition .
tying sales: 4555 . Tying sales happen when a customer is required to buy one product only if the customer also buys a second product .
the financial crisis: 4567 . The collapse of the markets for these assets precipitated the financial crisis and led to the failure of Lehman Brothers , a major investment bank , numerous large commercial banks , such as Wachovia , and even the Federal National Mortgage Corporation ( Fannie Mae ) , which had to be nationalized — that is , taken over by the federal government .
the social costs: The social costs include the private costs of production incurred by the company and the external costs of pollution that are passed on to society .
the private market: When there is market failure , the private market fails to achieve efficient output , because either firms do not account for all costs incurred in the production of output and/or consumers do not account for all benefits obtained ( a positive externality ) .
countries: 4595 . Depending on their different income levels and political preferences , countries are likely to make different choices about allocative efficiency — that is , the choice between economic output and environmental protection along the production possibility frontier .
positive externalities: As you learned in Environmental Protection and Negative Externalities , positive externalities are beneficial spillovers to a third party , or parties . Consider the example of the Big Drug Company , which is planning its R&D budget for the next year .
intellectual property rights: 4607 . Intellectual property rights include patents , which give the inventor the exclusive legal right to make , use , or sell the invention for a limited time , and copyright laws , which give the author an exclusive legal right over works of literature , music , film / video , and pictures .
dna microarrays: 614 . DNA microarrays are methods used to detect gene expression by analyzing an array of DNA fragments that are fixed to a glass slide or a silicon chip to identify active genes and identify sequences .
Metabolomics: 618 . Metabolomics involves the study of small molecule metabolites found in an organism .
the metabolome: The metabolome is the complete set of metabolites that are related to the genetic makeup of an organism .
divergent evolution: When two species evolve in diverse directions from a common point , it is called divergent evolution .
some structures: 632 . Some structures exist in organisms that have no apparent function at all , and appear to be residual parts from a past common ancestor .
hybrid: If humans were to artificially intervene and fertilize the egg of a bald eagle with the sperm of an African fish eagle and a chick did hatch , that offspring , called a hybrid ( a cross between two species ) , would probably be infertile — unable to successfully reproduce after it reached maturity .
reproductive isolation: 644 . Reproductive isolation is the inability to interbreed .
autopolyploidy: In some cases , a polyploid individual will have two or more complete sets of chromosomes from its own species in a condition called autopolyploidy ( [ link ] ) .
hybrid individuals in many cases: 653 . Hybrid individuals in many cases can not form normally in the womb and simply do not survive past the embryonic stages .
hybrid sterility: In another postzygotic situation , reproduction leads to the birth and growth of a hybrid that is sterile and unable to reproduce offspring of their own ; this is called hybrid sterility .
Heritability: Heritability refers to the proportion of difference among people that is attributed to genetics .
assortative mating: One common form of mate choice , called assortative mating , is an individual ’s preference to mate with partners who are phenotypically similar to themselves .

the population: 677 . If natural selection favors an average phenotype , selecting against extreme variation , the population will undergo stabilizing selection ( [ link ] ) .
frequency: 680 . Another type of selection , called frequency - dependent selection , favors phenotypes that are either common ( positive frequency - dependent selection ) or rare ( negative frequency - dependent selection ) .
hypothesis states: 683 . The good genes hypothesis states that males develop these impressive ornaments to show off their efficient metabolism or their ability to fight disease .
branch point: The point where a split occurs , called a branch point , represents where a single lineage evolved into a distinct new one .
basal taxon: 690 . A lineage that evolved early from the root and remains unbranched is called basal taxon .
sister taxa: When two lineages stem from the same branch point , they are called sister taxa .
kingdom: Within each domain is a second category called a kingdom .
analogy or homoplasy: When similar characteristics occur because of environmental constraints and not due to a close evolutionary relationship , it is called an analogy or homoplasy .
maximum parsimony: 704 . To aid in the tremendous task of describing phylogenies accurately , scientists often use a concept called maximum parsimony , which means that events occurred in the simplest , most obvious way .
these individual virus particles: These individual virus particles are the infectious form of a virus outside the host cell .

other envelope proteins: Other envelope proteins are the matrix proteins that stabilize the envelope and often play a role in the assembly of progeny virions .

group iv viruses: 725 . Group IV viruses have ssRNA as their genome with a positive polarity .

the viral replication cycle: 731 . The viral replication cycle can produce dramatic biochemical and structural changes in the host cell , which may cause cell damage .
the infection: 737 . When infection of a cell by a bacteriophage results in the production of new virions , the infection is said to be productive .
latency: In a process called latency , these viruses can exist in nervous tissue for long periods of time without producing new virions , only to leave latency periodically and cause lesions in the skin where the virus replicates .

plant viruses: 746 . Plant viruses can be transmitted by a variety of vectors , through contact with an infected plant ’s sap , by living organisms such as insects and nematodes , and through pollen .
vertical transmission: 747 . one common symptom: One common symptom is hyperplasia , the abnormal proliferation of cells that causes the appearance of plant tumors known as galls .
live vaccines: Live vaccines are usually made by attenuating ( weakening ) the “ wild - type ” ( disease - causing ) virus by growing it in the laboratory in tissues or at temperatures different from what the virus is accustomed to in the host .

the oxygenation of the atmosphere: Cyanobacteria ( [ link ] ) began the oxygenation of the atmosphere .
one type: One type is composed of pseudopeptidoglycan , which is similar to peptidoglycan in morphology but contains different sugars in the polysaccharide chain .

epidemic: 792 . An epidemic is a disease that occurs in an unusually high number of individuals in a population at the same time .
pandemic: A pandemic is a widespread , usually worldwide , epidemic .

accessory pigments: When such cells are carrying out photosynthesis , their plastids are rich in the pigment chlorophyll a and a range of other pigments , called accessory pigments , which are involved in harvesting energy from light .
saprobes: 812 . Subtypes of heterotrophs , called saprobes , absorb nutrients from dead organisms or their organic wastes .

the anal pore: 818 . Waste particles are expelled by an exocytic vesicle that fuses at a specific region on the cell membrane , called the anal pore .

the roots of the plant: The roots of the plant connect with the underground parts of the fungus forming mycorrhizae .

dimorphic fungi: 827 . Dimorphic fungi can change from the unicellular to multicellular state depending on environmental conditions .
unicellular fungi: Unicellular fungi are generally referred to as yeasts .

homothallic: When both mating types are present in the same mycelium , it is called homothallic , or self - fertile .

homosporous: Seedless non - vascular plants produce only one kind of spore and are called homosporous .

many seedless plants: Many seedless plants produce sperm equipped with flagella that enable them to swim in a moist environment to the archegonia : the female gametangium .
non: Plants that lack vascular tissue , which is formed of specialized cells for the transport of water and nutrients , are referred to as non - vascular plants .

parenchyma: The tissue consists of conducting cells , known as tracheids , and supportive filler tissue , called parenchyma .

sporophylls: Pine cones , mature fronds of ferns , and flowers are all sporophylls — leaves that were modified structurally to bear sporangia .

both ends of each fragment: In pairwise - end sequencing , both ends of each fragment are analyzed for overlap .

proteomics: The study of the function of proteomes is called proteomics .
adaptation: 628 . A heritable trait that helps the survival and reproduction of an organism in its present environment is called an adaptation .
evolution: 631 . Over time , evolution led to changes in the shapes and sizes of these bones in different species , but they have maintained the same overall layout .
species: 636 . In the gradual speciation model , species diverge gradually over time in small steps .

the modern synthesis: 655 . In sum , the modern synthesis describes how evolutionary processes , such as natural selection , can affect a population ’s genetic makeup , and , in turn , how this can result in the gradual evolution of populations and species .
macroevolution: The theory also connects this change of a population over time , called microevolution , with the processes that gave rise to new species and higher taxonomic groups with widely divergent characters , called macroevolution .

polymorphic: 661 . Populations with two or more variations of particular characteristics are called polymorphic .
some individuals: 3650 . Some individuals are born without the ability to feel pain .
cline: One type of geographic variation , called a cline , can be seen as populations of a given species vary gradually across an ecological gradient .
two or more distinct phenotypes: 679 . Sometimes two or more distinct phenotypes can each have their advantages and be selected for by natural selection , while the intermediate phenotypes are , on average , less fit .
its phylogeny: 685 . In scientific terms , the evolutionary history and relationship of an organism or group of organisms is called its phylogeny .

taxon: The name at each level is also called a taxon .

themselves: In the North American Free Trade Agreement ( NAFTA ) , the United States , Canada , and Mexico pledged themselves to reduce trade barriers .

each parent: 3318 . Therefore , each parent contributes half the genetic information carried by the offspring ; the resulting physical characteristics of the offspring ( called the phenotype ) are determined by the interaction of genetic material supplied by the parents ( called the genotype ) .

the existence of explicit rules: 5517 . The existence of explicit rules refers to the way in which rules are outlined , written down , and standardized .
Michels: Michels ( 1911 ) suggested that all large organizations are characterized by the Iron Rule of Oligarchy , wherein an entire organization is ruled by a few elites .
positive sanctions: Positive sanctions are rewards given for conforming to norms .
cultural deviance theory: 5532 . Cultural deviance theory suggests that conformity to the prevailing cultural norms of lower - class society causes crime .
sociologist c. wright mills: 5535 . In his book The Power Elite ( 1956 ) , sociologist C. Wright Mills described the existence of what he dubbed the power elite , a small group of wealthy and influential people at the top of society who hold the power and resources .
secondary deviance: Secondary deviance occurs when a person ’s self - concept and behavior begin to change after his or her actions are labeled as deviant by members of society .

nonviolent crimes: Nonviolent crimes involve the destruction or theft of property but do not use force or the threat of force .
victimless: Crimes are called victimless when the perpetrator is not explicitly harming another person .
Medicalization: Medicalization refers to the process by which previously normal aspects of life are redefined as deviant and needing medical attention to remedy .
bipolar disorder: 5574 . And bipolar disorder is characterized by dramatic shifts in energy and mood , often affecting the individual ’s ability to carry out day - to - day tasks .
medical sociology: 5580 . If sociology is the systematic study of human behavior in society , medical sociology is the systematic study of how humans manage issues of health and illness , disease and disorders , and healthcare for both the sick and the healthy .
medical sociologists: Medical sociologists study the physical , mental , and social components of health and illness .
Media: Media is a term that refers to all print , digital , and electronic means of communication .
planned obsolescence: This strategy is called planned obsolescence , and it is the business practice of planning for a product to be obsolete or unusable from the time it is created .
Derealization: Derealization is conceptualized as a sense of “ unreality or detachment from , or unfamiliarity with , the world , be it individuals , inanimate objects , or all surroundings ” ( APA , 2013 , p. 303 ) .
these kinds of delusions: 4228 . These kinds of delusions are known as paranoid delusions , which involve the ( false ) belief that other people or agencies are plotting to harm the person .
people with schizophrenia: People with schizophrenia also may hold grandiose delusions , beliefs that one holds special power , unique knowledge , or is extremely important .
the dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia: The dopamine hypothesis of schizophrenia proposed that an overabundance of dopamine or too many dopamine receptors are responsible for the onset and maintenance of schizophrenia ( Snyder , 1976 ) .
the term personality: 4240 . The term personality refers loosely to one ’s stable , consistent , and distinctive way of thinking about , feeling , acting , and relating to the world .
people with personality disorders: People with personality disorders exhibit a personality style that differs markedly from the expectations of their culture , is pervasive and inflexible , begins in adolescence or early adulthood , and causes distress or impairment ( APA , 2013 ) .
cluster c disorders: Cluster C disorders include avoidant personality disorder , dependent personality disorder , and obsessive - compulsive personality disorder ( which is not the same thing as obsessive - compulsive disorder ) .
mood disorders: 4246 . Mood disorders ( [ link ] ) are characterized by severe disturbances in mood and emotions — most often depression , but also mania and elation ( Rothschild , 1999 ) .
the person \u2019s mood: 4255 . A person with bipolar disorder ( commonly known as manic depression ) often experiences mood states that vacillate between depression and mania ; that is , the person ’s mood is said to alternate from one emotional extreme to the other ( in contrast to unipolar , which indicates a persistently sad mood ) .
Rumination: Rumination is the repetitive and passive focus on the fact that one is depressed and dwelling on depressed symptoms , rather that distracting one ’s self from the symptoms or attempting to address them in an active , problem - solving manner ( Nolen - Hoeksema , 1991 ) .
Compulsions: 4267 . Compulsions are repetitive and ritualistic acts that are typically carried out primarily as a means to minimize the distress that obsessions trigger or to reduce the likelihood of a feared event ( APA , 2013 ) .
conditioning theories of panic disorder: 4282 . Conditioning theories of panic disorder propose that panic attacks are classical conditioning responses to subtle bodily sensations resembling those normally occurring when one is anxious or frightened ( Bouton , Mineka , & Barlow , 2001 ) .
this diathesis - stress model: This diathesis - stress model suggests that people with an underlying predisposition for a disorder ( i.e. , a diathesis ) are more likely than others to develop a disorder when faced with adverse environmental or psychological events ( i.e. , stress ) , such as childhood maltreatment , negative life events , trauma , and so on .
the dsm-5: 4297 . The DSM-5 also provides information about comorbidity ; the co - occurrence of two disorders .
this kind of test: This kind of test relies on one of the defense mechanisms proposed by Freud — projection — as a way to assess unconscious processes .
Schizophrenia: 4224 . Schizophrenia is a devastating psychological disorder that is characterized by major disturbances in thought , perception , emotion , and behavior .
disorganized thinking: 4230 . Disorganized thinking refers to disjointed and incoherent thought processes — usually detected by what a person says .
negative symptoms: 4233 . Negative symptoms are those that reflect noticeable decreases and absences in certain behaviors , emotions , or drives ( Green , 2001 ) .
symptoms of ptsd: Symptoms of PTSD include intrusive and distressing memories of the event , flashbacks ( states that can last from a few seconds to several days , during which the individual relives the event and behaves as if the event were occurring at that moment [ APA , 2013 ] ) , avoidance of stimuli connected to the event , persistently negative emotional states ( e.g. , fear , anger , guilt , and shame ) , feelings of detachment from others , irritability , proneness toward outbursts , and an exaggerated startle response ( jumpiness ) .
bipolar and related disorders: 4248 . Bipolar and related disorders are a group of disorders in which mania is the defining feature .
Mania: Mania is a state of extreme elation and agitation .
others: 4257 . During a manic episode , some experience a mood that is almost euphoric and become excessively talkative , sometimes spontaneously starting conversations with strangers ; others become excessively irritable and complain or make hostile comments .
hopelessness: According to this theory , hopelessness is an expectation that unpleasant outcomes will occur or that desired outcomes will not occur , and there is nothing one can do to prevent such outcomes .
people with hoarding disorder: People with hoarding disorder can not bear to part with personal possessions , regardless of how valueless or useless these possessions are .
the locus coeruleus may play a role: Neurobiological theories of panic disorder suggest that a region of the brain called the locus coeruleus may play a role in this disorder .

part of another disorder: A diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder requires that the diffuse worrying and apprehension characteristic of this disorder — what Sigmund Freud referred to as free - floating anxiety — is not part of another disorder , occurs more days than not for at least six months , and is accompanied by any three of the following symptoms : restlessness , difficulty concentrating , being easily fatigued , muscle tension , irritability , and sleep difficulties .
Wakefield: Wakefield argued that natural internal mechanisms — that is , psychological processes honed by evolution , such as cognition , perception , and learning — have important functions , such as enabling us to experience the world the way others do and to engage in rational thought , problem solving , and communication .
trait theorists: 4299 . Trait theorists believe personality can be understood via the approach that all people have certain traits , or characteristic ways of behaving .
person taking the tat: A person taking the TAT is shown 8–12 ambiguous pictures and is asked to tell a story about each picture .
the european union: 7018 . The European Union is the single supranational entity with some real and significant authority over its member nations .
the national security act: The National Security Act governs the way the government shares and stores information , while the Patriot Act ( passed immediately after 9/11 ) clarifies what the government may do in collecting information about people in the name of protecting the country .
the director of national intelligence: 7048 . Even more important on intelligence than the CIA director is the director of national intelligence , a position created in the government reorganizations after 9/11 , who oversees the entire intelligence community in the U.S. government .
sand: Soil particles that are 0.1 to 2 mm in diameter are sand .
microbial processes: 1221 . Topsoil is rich in organic material ; microbial processes occur there , and it is the “ workhorse ” of plant production .

scutellum: In monocots , such as corn and wheat , the single cotyledon is called a scutellum ; the scutellum is connected directly to the embryo via vascular tissue ( xylem and phloem ) .
the radicle: 1260 . The portion of the embryo between the cotyledon attachment point and the radicle is known as the hypocotyl ( hypocotyl means “ below the cotyledons ” ) .
some seeds: Some seeds require vernalization ( cold treatment ) before they can germinate .
Layering: 1278 . Layering is a method in which a stem attached to the plant is bent and covered with soil .
polycarpic plants: Polycarpic plants form flowers many times during their lifetime .
the ground substance: The ground substance is made of an organic substance ( usually a protein ) and an inorganic substance ( usually a mineral or water ) .
fibrous connective tissues: 1308 . Fibrous connective tissues contain large amounts of collagen fibers and few cells or matrix material .

Carnivores: 1323 . Carnivores are animals that eat other animals .
Ruminants: 1329 . Ruminants are mainly herbivores like cows , sheep , and goats , whose entire diet consists of eating large amounts of roughage or fiber .
sphincter forms valves: 1335 . A ring - like muscle called a sphincter forms valves in the digestive system .
chyme: The partially digested food and gastric juice mixture is called chyme .
the human small intestine: 1341 . The human small intestine is over 6 m long and is divided into three parts : the duodenum , the jejunum , and the ileum .

the gallbladder: 1350 . The gallbladder is a small organ that aids the liver by storing bile and concentrating bile salts .
pancreatic juices: 1356 . Pancreatic juices also contain amylase , which continues the breakdown of starch and glycogen into maltose , a disaccharide .
gastric inhibitory peptide is secreted b: A hormone called gastric inhibitory peptide is secreted by the small intestine to slow down the peristaltic movements of the intestine to allow fatty foods more time to be digested and absorbed .
action potential: Transmission of a signal within a neuron ( from dendrite to axon terminal ) is carried by a brief reversal of the resting membrane potential called an action potential .
signal summationsometimes: 1392 . Signal SummationSometimes a single EPSP is strong enough to induce an action potential in the postsynaptic neuron , but often multiple presynaptic inputs must create EPSPs around the same time for the postsynaptic neuron to be sufficiently depolarized to fire an action potential .
sulci: There are three different ways that a brain can be sectioned in order to view internal structures : a sagittal section cuts the brain left to right , as shown in [ link ] b , a coronal section cuts the brain front to back , as shown in [ link ] a , and a horizontal section cuts the brain top to bottom . Cerebral CortexThe outermost part of the brain is a thick piece of nervous system tissue called the cerebral cortex , which is folded into hills called gyri ( singular : gyrus ) and valleys called sulci ( singular : sulcus ) .
the rest of the brain: 1416 . The brainstem , illustrated in [ link ] , connects the rest of the brain with the spinal cord .
the sympathetic nervous system: 1419 . The sympathetic nervous system is responsible for the “ fight or flight ” response that occurs when an animal encounters a dangerous situation .
neurodegenerative disorders: 1425 . Neurodegenerative disorders are illnesses characterized by a loss of nervous system functioning that are usually caused by neuronal death .
neurodevelopmental disorder: 1428 . Autism spectrum disorder ( ASD ) is a neurodevelopmental disorder .
major depression: 1431 . Major depression affects approximately 6.7 percent of the adults in the United States each year and is one of the most common mental disorders .
all: 1434 . Although the sensory systems associated with these senses are very different , all share a common function : to convert a stimulus ( such as light , or sound , or the position of the body ) into an electrical signal in the nervous system .
muscle spindles: Muscle spindles are stretch receptors that detect the amount of stretch , or lengthening of muscles .
audition , or hearing: 1449 . Audition , or hearing , is important to humans and to other animals for many different interactions .
the site of transduction: 1461 . The site of transduction is in the organ of Corti ( spiral organ ) .
the main photopigment , rhodopsin: In vertebrates , the main photopigment , rhodopsin , has two main parts [ link ] ) : an opsin , which is a membrane protein ( in the form of a cluster of α - helices that span the membrane ) , and retinal — a molecule that absorbs light .
the primary organ of taste: 1485 . The primary organ of taste is the taste bud .
papillae: A taste bud is a cluster of gustatory receptors ( taste cells ) that are located within the bumps on the tongue called papillae ( singular : papilla ) ( illustrated in [ link ] ) .
the steroid hormones: The primary class of lipid hormones in humans is the steroid hormones .
first messenger: The hormone that initiates the signaling pathway is called a first messenger , which activates a second messenger in the cytoplasm , as illustrated in [ link ] .

neural stimuli: 1503 . In some cases , the nervous system directly stimulates endocrine glands to release hormones , which is referred to as neural stimuli .
colloid: These follicles contain a viscous fluid , called colloid , which stores the glycoprotein thyroglobulin , the precursor to the thyroid hormones .
the chain termination method: The chain termination method involves DNA replication of a single - stranded template with the use of a primer and a regular deoxynucleotide ( dNTP ) , which is a monomer , or a single unit , of DNA .
contig: A larger sequence that is assembled from overlapping shorter sequences is called a contig .

proteome: 615 . A proteome is the entire set of proteins produced by a cell type .
false negative: A false negative is an incorrect test result that should have been positive .
microbiology: 624 . Traditionally , microbiology has been taught with the view that microorganisms are best studied under pure culture conditions , which involves isolating a single type of cell and culturing it in the laboratory .

new species: In the punctuated equilibrium model , a new species undergoes changes quickly from the parent species , and then remains largely unchanged for long periods of time afterward ( [ link ] ) .
mechanisms for speciation :: 639 . Given the extraordinary diversity of life on the planet there must be mechanisms for speciation : the formation of two species from one original species .
allopolyploid: 645 . The other form of polyploidy occurs when individuals of two different species reproduce to form a viable offspring called an allopolyploid .
behavioral isolation: 651 . Behavioral isolation occurs when the presence or absence of a specific behavior prevents reproduction from taking place .

genetic variance: 663 . The diversity of alleles and genotypes within a population is called genetic variance .
another important evolutionary force: 669 . Another important evolutionary force is gene flow : the flow of alleles in and out of a population due to the migration of individuals or gametes ( [ link ] ) .
populations: 678 . When the environment changes , populations will often undergo directional selection ( [ link ] ) , which selects for phenotypes at one end of the spectrum of existing variation .

some individual prokaryotes: 711 . As shown in [ link ] a , some individual prokaryotes were responsible for transferring the bacteria that caused mitochondrial development to the new eukaryotes , whereas other species transferred the bacteria that gave rise to chloroplasts .
cytopathic effects: 732 . These changes , called cytopathic ( causing cell damage ) effects , can change cell functions or even destroy the cell .
prions and viroids: 756 . Prions and viroids are pathogens ( agents with the ability to cause disease ) that have simpler structures than viruses but , in the case of prions , still can produce deadly diseases .

hydrothermal vent: A hydrothermal vent is a breakage or fissure in the Earth ’s surface that releases geothermally heated water .

extremophiles: 768 . Other bacteria and archaea are adapted to grow under extreme conditions and are called extremophiles , meaning “ lovers of extremes . ” Extremophiles have been found in all kinds of environments : the depth of the oceans , hot springs , the Artic and the Antarctic , in very dry places , deep inside Earth , in harsh chemical environments , and in high radiation environments ( [ link ] ) , just to mention a few .
the prokaryote: 780 . In transformation , the prokaryote takes in DNA found in its environment that is shed by other prokaryotes .
decomposers: Then , bacteria and fungi , collectively called decomposers , carry out the breakdown ( decomposition ) of plants and animals and their organic compounds .

these protists: These protists exist in freshwater and marine habitats , and are a component of plankton , the typically microscopic organisms that drift through the water and serve as a crucial food source for larger aquatic organisms .
unicellular heterotrophic protists: 822 . Foraminiferans , or forams , are unicellular heterotrophic protists , ranging from approximately 20 micrometers to several centimeters in length , and occasionally resembling tiny snails ( [ link ] ) .
