the result of mycology: Progress in the field of fungal biology was the result of mycology : the scientific study of fungi .
the zygomycetes: 843 . The zygomycetes are a relatively small group of fungi belonging to the Phylum Zygomycota .
the ascocarp: During sexual reproduction , thousands of asci fill a fruiting body called the ascocarp .

meaning fungus: Mycorrhiza , which comes from the Greek words myco meaning fungus and rhizo meaning root , refers to the association between vascular plant roots and their symbiotic fungi .

the female gametophyte: 864 . In both seedless and seed plants , the female gametophyte provides protection and nutrients to the embryo as it develops into the new generation of sporophyte .

the embryo: The embryo develops inside the archegonium as the sporophyte .

paraphyletic groups: Paraphyletic groups are those in which not all members are descendants of a single common ancestor .
male and female sporangia: Male and female sporangia are produced either on the same plant , described as monoecious ( “ one home ” or bisexual ) , or on separate plants , referred to as dioecious ( “ two homes ” or unisexual ) plants .

divided government: Divided government occurs when one or more houses of the legislature are controlled by the party in opposition to the executive .

the answer: 6547 . The answer is that they likely prefer to do something else and realize they can receive the same grade as the rest of the group without contributing to the effort .

for bicameralism: As a result , Virginia ’s delegates proposed a plan that called for bicameralism , or the division of legislators into two separate assemblies .
conference committee: A conference committee is used to reconcile different bills passed in both the House and the Senate .

the concept of collective representation: 6646 . The concept of collective representation describes the relationship between Congress and the United States as a whole .
the programs: 4642 . The programs are paid for through the federal income tax , which is a progressive tax system designed in such a way that the rich pay a higher percent in income taxes than the poor .
the seller of a good: 4675 . In the goods market , the seller of a good might offer a money - back guarantee , an agreement that functions as a promise of quality .
all workers: 4690 . Retirement insurance : All workers pay a percentage of their income into Social Security and into Medicare , which then provides income and health care benefits to the elderly .
insurance policies: For example , insurance policies often have deductibles , which is an amount that the insurance policyholder must pay out of their own pocket before the insurance coverage starts paying .
bondholder: Anyone who owns a bond and receives the interest payments is called a bondholder .
dividend: A firm can make a direct payment to its shareholders , called a dividend .
the actual rate of return: The actual rate of return refers to the total rate of return , including capital gains and interest paid on an investment at the end of a period of time .
companies: To simplify the process , companies offer mutual funds , which are organizations that buy a range of stocks or bonds from different companies .
president obama and congress: In September 2009 , President Obama and Congress enacted a tariff ( taxes added on imported goods ) on tires imported from China that would increase the import price of Chinese tires by 35 percent in its first year , 30 percent in its second year , and 25 percent in its third year .
the nnp: The NNP can be further subdivided into national income , which includes all income to businesses and individuals , and personal income , which includes only income to people .
this question: This question can be answered by calculating a country ’s GDP per capita ; that is , the GDP divided by the population .
labor productivity: Labor productivity is the value that each employed person creates per unit of his or her input .

all of these individuals: All of these individuals fall under the umbrella of the term “ hidden unemployment . ” Discouraged workers , those who have stopped looking for employment and , hence , are no longer counted in the unemployed also fall into this group

labor unions: 4882 . In the 1970s and 1980s , labor unions commonly negotiated wage contracts that had cost - of - living adjustments ( COLAs ) which guaranteed that their wages would keep up with inflation .
investors: In this novel business arrangement , which was in many ways the precursor to the modern corporation , investors provided the capital for and assumed the risk of a venture in order to reap significant returns .
traditional economies: Traditional economies organize their economic affairs the way they have always done ( i.e. , tradition ) .
the rise of globalizationrecent decades: 4334 . The Rise of GlobalizationRecent decades have seen a trend toward globalization , which is the expanding cultural , political , and economic connections between people around the world .
common pattern: 4343 . The general pattern that consumption of the first few units of any good tends to bring a higher level of utility to a person than consumption of later units is a common pattern .
inefficient machine: An inefficient machine operates at high cost , while an efficient machine operates at lower cost , because it is not wasting energy or materials .

the third theme: 4358 . The third theme is economic efficiency , or getting the most benefit from scarce resources .

constant unitary elasticity: 4373 . Constant unitary elasticity , in either a supply or demand curve , occurs when a price change of one percent results in a quantity change of one percent .
the income elasticity of demand: The income elasticity of demand is the percentage change in quantity demanded divided by the percentage change in income .

variable costs: 4391 . Variable costs , on the other hand , are incurred in the act of producing — the more you produce , the greater the variable cost .
demand curve: A demand curve shows the relationship between price and quantity demanded on a graph like [ link ] , with quantity on the horizontal axis and the price per gallon on the vertical axis .
supply curve: A supply curve is a graphic illustration of the relationship between price , shown on the vertical axis , and quantity , shown on the horizontal axis .
normal good: A product whose demand rises when income rises , and vice versa , is called a normal good .
substitute: A substitute is a good or service that can be used in place of another good or service .
price controls: Price controls are government laws that serve to regulate prices rather than allow the various markets to determine prices .

participants in financial markets: 4448 . Participants in financial markets must decide when they prefer to consume goods : now or in the future .

sellers and buyers: 4478 . Firms are said to be in perfect competition when the following conditions occur : ( 1 ) many firms produce identical products ; ( 2 ) many buyers are available to buy the product , and many sellers are available to sell the product ; ( 3 ) sellers and buyers have all relevant information to make rational decisions about the product being bought and sold ; and ( 4 ) firms can enter and leave the market without any restrictions — in other words , there is free entry and exit into and out of the market .
entry: When new firms enter the industry in response to increased industry profits it is called entry .
one firm: In the case of monopoly , one firm produces all of the output in a market .

marginal profit: 4508 . [ link ] repeats the marginal cost and marginal revenue data from [ link ] , and adds two more columns : Marginal profit is the profitability of each additional unit sold .

economists: Instead , economists use game theory , a branch of mathematics that analyzes situations in which players must make decisions and then receive payoffs based on what other players decide to do .

narrowly defined market: A narrowly defined market will tend to make concentration appear higher , while a broadly defined market will tend to make it appear smaller . Feynman: Feynman was one of the theorists who developed the field of quantum electrodynamics ( QED ) , which is the quantum mechanics of electromagnetism .
boson: First mentioned in Patterns in Spectra Reveal More Quantization , a boson is a particle with zero or an integer value of intrinsic spin ( such as s = 0 , 1 , 2 , ... s = 0 , 1 , 2 , ... size 12 { s = 0 , `1 , `2 , `  .
the standard model: So successful have QCD and the electroweak theory been that , taken together , they are called the Standard Model .
quantum gravity: Quantum gravity is the theory that deals with particle exchange of gravitons as the mechanism for the force , and with extreme conditions where quantum mechanics and general relativity must both be used .
dark matter: The indirectly observed non - luminous matter is called dark matter .
universe that is closed: A universe that is closed is called positively curved .
Superconductors: 3299 . Superconductors are materials with a resistivity of zero .
sonic boom: This superposition forms a disturbance called a sonic boom , a constructive interference of sound created by an object moving faster than sound .
synchrotron radiation: Radiation caused by a magnetic field accelerating a charged particle perpendicular to its velocity is called synchrotron radiation in honor of its importance in these machines .
Science: Science may be better defined as fields of study that attempt to comprehend the nature of the universe .
peer - reviewed manuscripts: Peer - reviewed manuscripts are scientific papers that are reviewed by a scientist ’s colleagues , or peers .
example of a macromolecule: An example of a macromolecule is deoxyribonucleic acid ( DNA ) ( [ link ] ) , which contains the instructions for the structure and functioning of all living organisms .
the cells of eukaryotes: Prokaryotes are single - celled or colonial organisms that do not have membrane - bound nuclei ; in contrast , the cells of eukaryotes do have membrane - bound organelles and a membrane - bound nucleus .
organ system: An organ system is a higher level of organization that consists of functionally related organs .
Cations: Cations are positive ions that are formed by losing electrons .
ionic bonds: 79 . Ionic bonds are formed between ions with opposite charges .
the electrons: In a polar covalent bond , shown in [ link ] , the electrons are unequally shared by the atoms and are attracted more to one nucleus than the other .
hydrogen bonds: 94 . The charges associated with these molecules will form hydrogen bonds with water , surrounding the particle with water molecules .
Dissociation: Dissociation occurs when atoms or groups of atoms break off from molecules and form ions .
these cohesive forces: 97 . These cohesive forces are related to water ’s property of adhesion , or the attraction between water molecules and other molecules .
acid: An acid is a substance that increases the concentration of hydrogen ions ( H+ ) in a solution , usually by having one of its hydrogen atoms dissociate .
base: A base provides either hydroxide ions ( OH – ) or other negatively charged ions that combine with hydrogen ions , reducing their concentration in the solution and thereby raising the pH .
Buffers: Buffers readily absorb excess H+ or OH – , keeping the pH of the body carefully maintained in the narrow range required for survival .
functional groups: 112 . Functional groups are groups of atoms that occur within molecules and confer specific chemical properties to those molecules .
dehydration reactions: 118 . Dehydration and hydrolysis reactions are catalyzed , or “ sped up , ” by specific enzymes ; dehydration reactions involve the formation of new bonds , requiring energy , while hydrolysis reactions break bonds and release energy .
the exoskeleton: Arthropods ( insects , crustaceans , and others ) have an outer skeleton , called the exoskeleton , which protects their internal body parts ( as seen in the bee in [ link ] ) .
arachidic acid: Arachidic acid is derived from Arachis hypogea , the scientific name for groundnuts or peanuts .
Hormones: 139 . Hormones are chemical - signaling molecules , usually small proteins or steroids , secreted by endocrine cells that act to control or regulate specific physiological processes , including growth , development , metabolism , and reproduction .
each amino acid: Each amino acid is attached to another amino acid by a covalent bond , known as a peptide bond , which is formed by a dehydration reaction .
both structures: Both structures are the α - helix structure — the helix held in shape by hydrogen bonds .
the dna molecules: 151 . The DNA molecules never leave the nucleus but instead use an intermediary to communicate with the rest of the cell .
microscope: A microscope is an instrument that magnifies an object .
micrographs: Most photographs of cells are taken with a microscope , and these images can also be called micrographs . The optics of a microscope ’s lenses change the orientation of the image that the user sees .
the nucleoplasm: The nucleoplasm is the semi - solid fluid inside the nucleus , where we find the chromatin and the nucleolus .
the nucleolus aggregates the ribosomal: A darkly staining area within the nucleus called the nucleolus ( plural = nucleoli ) aggregates the ribosomal RNA with associated proteins to assemble the ribosomal subunits that are then transported out through the pores in the nuclear envelope to the cytoplasm .
Peroxisomes: 178 . Peroxisomes are small , round organelles enclosed by single membranes .
the lysosomes: The lysosomes are the cell ’s “ garbage disposal . ”
chlorophyll: The chloroplasts contain a green pigment called chlorophyll , which captures the light energy that drives the reactions of photosynthesis .
actin: They function in cellular movement , have a diameter of about 7 nm , and are made of two intertwined strands of a globular protein called actin ( [ link ] ) .
plasmodesmata: There also exist structural modifications called plasmodesmata ( singular = plasmodesma ) , numerous channels that pass between cell walls of adjacent plant cells , connect their cytoplasm , and enable materials to be transported from cell to cell , and thus throughout the plant ( [ link ] ) .
gap junctions in animal cells: 196 . Gap junctions in animal cells are like plasmodesmata in plant cells in that they are channels between adjacent cells that allow for the transport of ions , nutrients , and other substances that enable cells to communicate ( [ link ] ) .
integral proteins: Integral proteins ( some specialized types are called integrins ) are , as their name suggests , integrated completely into the membrane structure , and their hydrophobic membrane - spanning regions interact with the hydrophobic region of the the phospholipid bilayer ( [ link ] ) .
passive transport: Passive transport is a naturally occurring phenomenon and does not require the cell to exert any of its energy to accomplish the movement .
the rate of diffusion: 208 . In filtration , material moves according to its concentration gradient through a membrane ; sometimes the rate of diffusion is enhanced by pressure , causing the substances to filter more rapidly .
Osmolarity: Osmolarity describes the total solute concentration of the solution .
its electrochemical gradient: The combined gradient of concentration and electrical charge that affects an ion is called its electrochemical gradient .
secondary active transport: Secondary active transport describes the movement of material that is due to the electrochemical gradient established by primary active transport that does not directly require ATP .
antiporter: An antiporter also carries two different ions or molecules , but in different directions .
Endocytosis: 232 . Endocytosis is a type of active transport that moves particles , such as large molecules , parts of cells , and even whole cells , into a cell .
caveolin: This process uses a coating protein , called caveolin , on the cytoplasmic side of the plasma membrane , which performs a similar function to clathrin .
Exocytosis: Exocytosis is the opposite of the processes discussed above in that its purpose is to expel material from the cell into the extracellular fluid .
anabolic pathways: 241 . Anabolic pathways require an input of energy to synthesize complex molecules from simpler ones .
heat energy: Thermodynamically , heat energy is defined as the energy transferred from one system to another that is not doing work .
these reactions: 253 . These reactions have a net release of energy , but still require some energy in the beginning .
ATP: ATP is a small , relatively simple molecule ( [ link ] ) , but within some of its bonds , it contains the potential for a quick burst of energy that can be harnessed to perform cellular work .
the enzyme 's active site: The location within the enzyme where the substrate binds is called the enzyme ’s active site .
the enzyme: When this happens , the enzyme is inhibited through competitive inhibition , because an inhibitor molecule competes with the substrate for active site binding ( [ link ] ) .
inhibitor molecule: On the other hand , in noncompetitive inhibition , an inhibitor molecule binds to the enzyme in a location other than an allosteric site and still manages to block substrate binding to the active site .
feedback inhibition: Feedback inhibition involves the use of a reaction product to regulate its own further production ( [ link ] ) .
Phosphorylation: Phosphorylation refers to the addition of the phosphate ( ~P ) .
oxidative phosphorylation: The production of ATP using the process of chemiosmosis is called oxidative phosphorylation because of the involvement of oxygen in the process .
pyruvate: These transporters assist in the facilitated diffusion of glucose . Glycolysis begins with the six carbon ring - shaped structure of a single glucose molecule and ends with two molecules of a three - carbon sugar called pyruvate .
the endoplasmic reticulum: 280 . The endoplasmic reticulum ( ER ) ( [ link ] ) is a series of interconnected membranous sacs and tubules that collectively modifies proteins and synthesizes lipids .
place: Sorting , tagging , packaging , and distribution of lipids and proteins takes place in the Golgi apparatus ( also called the Golgi body ) , a series of flattened membranes ( [ link ] ) .
the mesophyll: The process of photosynthesis occurs in a middle layer called the mesophyll .
